newsitem.title: KENYA: RALLYING-MCRAE SURVIVES SABOTAGE ATTEMPT TO LEAD.
newsitem.headline: RALLYING-MCRAE SURVIVES SABOTAGE ATTEMPT TO LEAD.

text.p: Colin McRae was fortunate to remain in Kenya's Safari Rally on Sunday after spectators tried to sabotage his car on the second day's sixth stage.

Briton McRae, who led by more than eight minutes from Kenyan Ian Duncan in a Toyota after the seventh stage, lost three minutes at the service point after the incident, which damaged his steering rack, broke a wishbone and caused a puncture.
"There was a one foot (30-cm) high wall of stones and we hit it flat out," said the Subaru driver.
"The car jumped in the air and I thought we had taken the whole front end off. Luckily, we just damaged one corner very badly."
McRae took the lead in the morning's first stage, the fifth of the event.
Overnight leader German Armin Schwarz in a Ford encountered suspension problems which caused the tread on his tyres to peel off and he dropped to fourth.
Briton Richard Burns, second until the seventh stage, dropped to third when he stopped to mend a puncture and his Mitsubishi fell off the jack.
World champion Tommi Makinen became the latest casualty when he had three punctures in the fifth stage and was unable to continue the race.
The rally has already claimed world championship leaders Carlos Sainz of Spain and Kenneth Eriksson of Sweden, who both retired on the opening day.
